Knowledge Point: Hiatus across word boundaries is usually avoided. There are two strategies. The first and generally used one is the elision of the last vowel of the first word if it is a weak vowel (ə and ɐ, both spelled <a>), as in \textit{Quaj \textbf{vèz' ò} uschéja} `This looks like that' instead of vèza ò. Example (\ref{ex:sandhi1}) contains two examples of the weak vowel <a> which is elided (bigj' idéa for bigja idéa and stad' ajn for stada ajn), a well as one example of strong \isi{vowels} that do not trigger elision (ju èra).

Knowledge Point: The other, much less frequent strategy, is to insert an \isi{epenthetic n} between the two words as in (\ref{ex:euphonic1}), where n is inserted between vasèva and ins.

There are some cases of assimilation of \isi{consonants} across word boundaries. In (\ref{ex:ass1}), détg di `said to' is realised as [detːi], and in (\ref{ex:ass2}), détg: té `said: you' is pronounced [detːe].

A major problem in analysing \isi{consonants} is the question whether the \isi{voiceless} word final \isi{consonants} should be considered as such or as underlyingly voiced. For instance, in \ili{Standard Sursilvan} the 1st person singular \isi{conditional} is written cantass `I would sing', but in Tuatschin when followed by a vowel or a voiced consonant, it is pronounced /z/, as in stèṣ /ʃtɛz/ (\ref{ex:stes}).
